In mantle of Proteus clad,</br>With aspect ferocious and wild,</br>Now pleasant, now sullen and sad,</br>Now froward, now placid and mild,</br>In his hand, from the Zodiac fled,</br>The Aries progressive is seen,</br>The almond her blossoms has shed</br>Around his unciviliz'd mien.

'Tis March — how tremendous they blow!</br>Unprison'd what tempests arise</br>From the caverns of Boreas below!</br>The hills feel the blasts of the skies.</br>The hills echo loud, and the deep</br>Ascends in big surges of foam;</br>The ships o'er the precipice sweep,</br>Through perils implacable roam.

Ye winds, your rude tumults assuage;</br>O cease your wild thunders to pour;</br>Forbear your tyrannical rage;</br>O hear the young Season deplore!</br>Let morning your friendship resume,</br>Revive Nature's low-bending head,</br>Send Zephyr on soft silken plume,</br>The breath of Favonious to spread.

'Tis done:  on the banks of the rill</br>Peeps the primrose in straw-colour'd vest;</br>By the side of the gay daffodil</br>Beams the topaz of Flora confest.</br>The daisy besprinkles the plain;</br>What lustre the crocus unfolds!</br>In yellow and purple her train</br>The eye with soft pleasure beholds.

The alders their bunches unfold,</br>And see, on the hedge-rows suspend</br>The sallow's soft fringes of gold,</br>With leaves of the suckle to blend.</br>When breathes the sweet South by the bank,</br>The pilewort shines forth by the rill,</br>But the violet alone we must thank,</br>From her all our odours distill.

Does the bee burst her hive in the morn,</br>There Aether piratical sail;</br>Sure sign that our fields shall adorn,</br>That Flora's alive on the Dale.</br>Sure sign that no storms will arise,</br>The face of the day to obscure,</br>But mild and unclouded the skies</br>The present Serene will insure.

Behold the young lamb in the fold,</br>A spectacle pleasing and sweet;</br>O save it new-dropt from the fold,</br>For feeble and weak are its feet.</br>The office is soft, and the care</br>'Tis innocence meekly intreats,</br>To the cottage, O take him, ye fair,</br>And feed him whenever he bleats.

From the bough tho' tis naked and bare,</br>The throstle melodious sings;</br>The rooks render vocal the air</br>In the tole with industrious wings,</br>The colony formed to defend,</br>Their new habitations we see,</br>Some labour and loaded ascend,</br>Whilst others to plunder agree.

The Muse might comparison draw,</br>And liken this scene to a state</br>Where anarchy tramples on law;</br>But fears the bold thought to relate.</br>But let her idea compare</br>The Rooks to a newly form'd clan;</br>Who the standard of government rear,</br>Without either order or plan.

What gifts for my fair shall I bring,</br>The primrose and March violet gay;</br>Such innocent poesies of spring</br>My purest affection convey.</br>She comes as the Moon from a cloud,</br>My snow-bosom'd Delia appears,</br>With the soul of a mild virtue endow'd,</br>And her cheeks unpolluted with tears.

The smiles and the buds of the grove</br>Instantaneous their foliage expand;</br>Rob'd in all the mild lustres of love,</br>A lambkin she leads in her hand.</br>It was the first born of the fold;</br>Which but for her care had been lost;</br>Her tenderness sav'd from the cold</br>The fatal effects of the frost.

She smiles; and, elate with the sound</br>Of bells from the hamlet below,</br>Festivity bids to abound,</br>The cause every shepherd must know.</br>And bear that Selander the gay,</br>To Melicent fortunate hind,</br>By Hymen on this happy day</br>The bridegroom of transport was joined.

Did Hymen e'er look with more grace?</br>The Muse is invited a guest:</br>Was ever more chearful his face</br>Than on this pleasing union express'd?</br>Ye shepherds, convene on the lea,</br>Let mirth the most sprightly be ours:</br>Go, Delia, announce the decree,</br>And call up the musical powers.

The crocus of flame-colour'd hue,</br>The hyacinth varied in vest,</br>The sweet polyanthuses too,</br>And anemonies wantonly dress'd.</br>The mizerian worthy of praise,</br>Tho' fraught with no lavish perfume,</br>And willow whose silver-like rays,</br>Are shed from its white velvet bloom.

These let us collect, and we'll weave</br>A garland for Melicent's brow;</br>I'm certain the fair will receive</br>The gift which her shepherds bestow.</br>The Fair will the present approve,</br>And gratefully honour my lay;</br>'Tis, Nature, the union of love,</br>Be ever recorded the day.

Selander, O long be thou blest,</br>Long cherish the maid of thy heart,</br>Dear choice of his unreserv'd breast,</br>A passion that's mutual impart.</br>So your loves shall no trouble annoy,</br>But Hymen perpetually sing,</br>That March was the parent of joy,</br>As well as the father of Spring.</br>
